content.body: Jake Archibald: it tests that foO gets through Access-Control-Allow-Methods: foO, which doesn't work for the same reason I think

content.body: annevk that test would pass if the ACAM check was case insensitive. Chrome is currently allowing methods that the server didn't allow, which seems bad ðŸ˜¬

content.body: Ah, Hiroshi has tests for that https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/pull/29680/files#diff-1166b97b413b5886babae2b10bae70526b1b9ff70b5feeb3c658177a2fa3f556R79

> <@annevk:mozilla.org> And to merge "Obsolete features" back into the main body of the specification

If we move the Obsolete Features content, we should make sure to preserve the IDs ãƒ¼ because MDN has links to some of it
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
And to merge "Obsolete features" back into the main body of the specification
If we move the Obsolete Features content, we should make sure to preserve the IDs ãƒ¼ because MDN has links to some of it

content.body: This is another reason why I don't think MDN should be linking to any spec parts about obsolete content to begin with, and why I never added such links myself. But others see it differently, so we do have a few of those in MDN
sideshowbarker: interesting, kinda surprising MDN cares about them indeed, but we should preserve IDs anyway as source code or bug comments are likely to link it too
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: interesting, kinda surprising MDN cares about them indeed, but we should preserve IDs anyway as source code or bug comments are likely to link it too

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> The main thing I can think of is to split each element section into two sections, one for authors and one for implementers

Big +1 to that. Whatever we can do to further clearly separate author-conformance requirements from implementor requirements is a win for everybody
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
The main thing I can think of is to split each element section into two sections, one for authors and one for implementers
Big +1 to that. Whatever we can do to further clearly separate author-conformance requirements from implementor requirements is a win for everybody
